header.emu_comment: The Satellaview is a satellite modem peripheral for Nintendos Super Famicom system that was released in Japan in 1995. Available for pre-release orders beginning February 13, 1995, the Satellaview retailed for between 14,000 and 18,000 yen (at the time between 141 and 182 USD) and came bundled with the BS-X Game Pak and an 8M Memory Pak.[CR]Developer: Nintendo[CR]Manufacturer: Nintendo[CR]CPU: 16-bit 65c816 Ricoh 5A22 3.58 MHz[CR]Memory: 128kb[CR]Graphics: N/A[CR]Sound: 8-bit Sony SPC700[CR]Display: 512 x 239[CR]Media: Cartridge[CR]Max. Controllers: 2

game.name: AK LIVE Hit Gang (4-28) + Chrono Trigger Unknown Magazine (Japan)
game.description: AK LIVE Hit Gang (4-28) + Chrono Trigger Unknown Magazine (Japan)
game.title_clean: AK LIVE Hit Gang + Chrono Trigger Unknown Magazine

game.name: Actraiser (Japan)
game.plot: ActRaiser is a Super Nintendo Entertainment System city-building simulation and action hybrid. The game was developed by Quintet and published by Enix (before their merge with Square), and the game was released during November of 1991.

game.name: Albert Odyssey (Japan)
game.plot: BS Albert Odyssey is a Strategy game, developed by SunSoft and published by Tokai Engineering, which was released in Japan in 1998.

game.name: Arkanoid - Doh It Again (Japan)
game.plot: BS Arkanoid: Doh It Again is an Action game, developed and published by Taito Corporation, which was released in Japan in 1997.

game.name: BS F-Zero Grand Prix - Dai-1-shuu - Knight League (Japan) (SoundLink)
game.description: BS F-Zero Grand Prix - Dai-1-shuu - Knight League (Japan) (SoundLink)
game.title_clean: BS F-Zero Grand Prix - Dai-1-shuu - Knight League
game.plot: BS F-Zero Grand Prix is a Downloadable 4-part Soundlink game for the Satellaview that was broadcast in at least 3 runs between December 29, 1996 and November 28, 1998. The game was broadcast as a pseudo-sequel to the F-ZERO series and it was followed by as many as 3 sequels entitled BS F-ZERO Grand Prix 2, BS F-ZERO 2, and BS F-ZERO 2 Grand Prix 2 (released in August, September, and October of 1997, respectively).

game.name: BS Marvelous - Camp Arnold Course - Dai-1-shuu (Japan) (SoundLink) [b]
game.description: BS Marvelous - Camp Arnold Course - Dai-1-shuu (Japan) (SoundLink) [b]
game.title_clean: BS Marvelous - Camp Arnold Course - Dai-1-shuu
game.plot: BS Marvelous: Camp Arnold is a Downloadable 4-part Soundlink game for the Satellaview that ran between November 3, 1996 and November 29, 1996. The game was broadcast as a rerun in January, 1997. BS Marvelous: Camp Arnold served as a sequel to the earlier-broadcast BS Marvelous: Time Athletics, released in January 1996, and a direct prequel to Marvelous: Mohitotsu no Takarajima which was not broadcast via Satellaview but instead released in hard copy as a SFC cartridge in October 1996.

game.plot: BS Marvelous: Time Athletics is a Downloadable 4-part Soundlink game for the Satellaview that ran between January 1, 1996 and January 31, 1996. The game was broadcast in as a rerun in April, 1996. A sequel to BS Marvelous: Time Athletics entitled BS Marvelous: Camp Arnold was released in November, 1996 as a direct prequel to Marvelous: Mohitotsu no Takarajima which was not broadcast via Satellaview but instead released in hard copy as a SFC cartridge.

game.name: BS Parlor! Parlor! - Dai-2-shuu (Japan) (3-13) (SoundLink)
game.plot: BS Parlor! Parlor! is a Downloadable 2-part Soundlink game for the Satellaview that was broadcast between March 1, 1998 and March 14, 1998. At various times throughout 1995, the game was accompanied by full-day broadcasts of a strategy magazine entitled BS Parlor! Parlor! Kouryaku Magazine.

game.plot: BS Parlor! Parlor! is a Downloadable 2-part Soundlink game for the Satellaview that was broadcast between March 1, 1998 and March 14, 1998. At various times throughout 1995, the game was accompanied by full-day broadcasts of a strategy magazine entitled BS Parlor! Parlor! Kouryaku Magazine.

game.name: BS Super Mario Collection - Dai-3-shuu (Japan) (1-13) [b]
game.plot: BS Super Mario Collection is a remake of Super Mario Collection for the Satellaview. The game was released in four installments as a Soundlink game entry.

game.name: BS Super Mario Collection - Dai-3-shuu (Japan) (3-17) (SoundLink)
game.plot: BS Super Mario Collection is a remake of Super Mario Collection for the Satellaview. The game was released in four installments as a Soundlink game entry.

game.description: BS Super Mario USA - Power Challenge - Dai-2-kai (Japan) (SoundLink)
game.title_clean: BS Super Mario USA - Power Challenge - Dai-2-kai
game.plot: BS Super Mario USA Power Challenge is an ura- or gaiden-version of Super Mario Bros. 2 for the Satellaview system featuring graphical enhancements similar to its Super Mario All-Stars version. While the underlying gameplay itself is largely similar, new and arranged content has been added. This is the week 2 release: "Secrets of the Quicksand that Surprises Even Tryclyde".

game.name: BS Zelda no Densetsu - Dai-2-wa (Japan) (SoundLink)
game.plot: BS Zelda no Densetsu is a Downloadable 4-part Soundlink game for the Satellaview that was broadcast in at least 5 distinct runs between August 6, 1995 and January 4, 1997. A program called BS Zelda no Asobikata was also broadcast in the half-hour prior to broadcasts of BS Zelda. This program seems to have been a radio tutorial teaching players how to play BS Zelda.

game.name: BS Zelda no Densetsu - Dai-3-wa (Japan) (SoundLink)
game.plot: BS Zelda no Densetsu is a Downloadable 4-part Soundlink game for the Satellaview that was broadcast in at least 5 distinct runs between August 6, 1995 and January 4, 1997. A program called BS Zelda no Asobikata was also broadcast in the half-hour prior to broadcasts of BS Zelda. This program seems to have been a radio tutorial teaching players how to play BS Zelda.

game.name: BS Zelda no Densetsu - Inishie no Sekiban - Dai-1-wa (Japan) (SoundLink)
game.description: BS Zelda no Densetsu - Inishie no Sekiban - Dai-1-wa (Japan) (SoundLink)
game.title_clean: BS Zelda no Densetsu - Inishie no Sekiban - Dai-1-wa
game.plot: BS Zelda no Densetsu: Inishie no Sekiban is a Downloadable 4-part Soundlink game for the Satellaview that was broadcast in at least 4 distinct runs between March 30, 1997 and May 30, 1999. The game has in the past been commonly referred to as "BS Zelda no Densetsu: Kodai no Sekiban", however the current fan consensus is that the term, is more appropriately written as "Inishie no Sekiban" due to the in-game SoundLink pronunciation of the game's title as heard on period VHS recordings of live game-play.

game.name: Bokujou Monogatari (Japan) (Demo) [b]
game.plot: BS Bokujou Monogatari is a Downloadable 4-part Soundlink game for the Satellaview that was broadcast in at least 2 runs between September 2, 1996 and November 30, 1996. The game is a life-simulation game and it comes as a pseudo-sequel to the earlier-broadcast (July 1996)/retail release Bokujou Monogatari commonly known internationally as "Harvest Moon"; this has given the series the fan-nickname "BS Harvest Moon" as a result. Together with the game (typically immediately before and after), 10-minute broadcasts of a related nature were released entitled BS Bokujou Monogatari Torisetsu (a digital instruction manual) and Bokujou Monogatari no Kekka (a score/results program).

game.name: Bokujou Monogatari - Dai-2-wa (Japan) (SoundLink)
game.plot: BS Bokujou Monogatari is a Downloadable 4-part Soundlink game for the Satellaview that was broadcast in at least 2 runs between September 2, 1996 and November 30, 1996. The game is a life-simulation game and it comes as a pseudo-sequel to the earlier-broadcast (July 1996)/retail release Bokujou Monogatari, commonly known internationally as "Harvest Moon"; this has given the series the fan-nickname "BS Harvest Moon" as a result. Together with the game (typically immediately before and after), 10-minute broadcasts of a related nature were released entitled BS Bokujou Monogatari Torisetsu (a digital instruction manual) and Bokujou Monogatari no Kekka (a score/results program).

game.name: Chrono Trigger - Jet Bike Special (Japan)
game.plot: Chrono Trigger is a game for the Super Famicom. From as early as May of 1995 it was discussed on the Satellaview broadcast magazine, Game Tora no Ooana.[CR]Later in the life of the Satellaview, downloadable content was released for Chrono Trigger via the Satellaview. These sets of download data included:[CR] Chrono Trigger Character Zukan[CR] Chrono Trigger Jet Bike Special[CR] Chrono Trigger Music Library

game.name: Chrono Trigger - Music Library (Japan)
game.plot: BS Chrono Trigger: Music Library was released for the Satellaview in 1995. The game was developed by Squaresoft and published by Nintendo. Essentially, Music Library is an add-on to Chrono Trigger. It contains the game's entire soundtrack, which can be selected and played based on disc and track number. The music is played in something like a media player, where the player has control over stopping and playing the music (but not fast-forwarding or rewinding).

game.name: Daibakushou Jinsei Gekijou (Japan)
game.plot: Daibakushou Jinseigekijou: Ooedo Nikki is a view-limited Downloadable game for the Satellaview that was broadcast in at least 4 runs between March 2, 1997 and February 21, 1998. From November 15, 1998 and onward, the game dropped its subtitle to become simply Daibakushou Jinseigekijou.

game.name: Darius Force (Japan)
game.plot: For countless millennia, the space tyrant Belser and his cosmic marauders have terrorized this once peaceful galaxy. Now, no sector remains safe from these stellar mercenaries and their evil empire. The Galactic Federation has finally called on two of its ace pilots and their sleek Silver Hawk warships to do battle with Belser's malicious metal menaces and reclaim the beloved planet Darius. Climb into the pilot's seat for a solo mission against Belser's forces; or engage the enemies with a fellow Federation pilot in a two-player simultaneous team attack. The future of the galaxy rests on the success of this perilous quest.

game.name: Dezaemon BSX Version - BS-X Shooting (Japan) (En)
game.plot: Dezaemon is an Action game, developed and published by Athena, which was released in Japan in 1994.

game.name: Dragon Slayer - Eiyuu Densetsu (Japan)
game.plot: Dragon Slayer: Eiyuu Densetsu is a view-limited Downloadable game for the Satellaview that was broadcast in at least 3 runs between August 31, 1997 and February 28, 1998.

game.name: Excitebike - Bunbun Mario Battle - Stadium 2 (Japan) (5-18) (SoundLink)
game.plot: Excitebike: BunBun Mario Battle Stadium is an obscure remake/adaptation of the NES title, Excitebike. In this game, all human bikers were replaced with Mario characters. The game was somewhat based on the Mario Kart series. As a Satellaview title, Nintendo developed the video game and released four versions of it through the satellite download service operated by St.GIGA, each expanding on or replacing the features of the last.

As a Satellaview title, Nintendo developed the video game and released four versions of it through the satellite download service operated by St.GIGA, each expanding on or replacing the features of the last.

game.name: F-Zero (Japan)
game.plot: The future of racing is here! F-ZERO, an intergalaxtic Grand Prix, uses machines that weigh more than a ton, reach dash speeds of over 500km/h and hover a mere twelve inches off the ground! Choose from the heroic Captain Falcon, or the suave, Dr. Stuart. Need more choices? Then try the sly alien, Pico or the not-so-honest Samurai Goroh, and race for intergalactic fame and fabulous fortune in the F-ZERO Grand Prix.

game.name: Firemen, The (Japan)
game.plot: The Firemen is a Downloadable Game for the Satellaview that was broadcast in at least 6 distinct runs between February 2, 1997 and January 24, 1998.

game.plot: A fun, four-player isometric mini-golf video game that will present the expected challenges of perfectly hitting the ball at the exact power and precise angle. Released on for Satellaview device and initially running between August 10, 1997 and August 23, 1997. The game was rebroadcast for at least 4 runs ending in March 30, 1998.

game.name: Kaizou Choujin Shubibinman Zero (Japan)
game.plot: Kaizou Choujin Schbibinman Zero is a view-limited Downloadable Game for the Satellaview that ran between March 30, 1997 and February 28, 1998. It is a pseudo-sequel to the earlier Kaizou Choujin Schbibinman and Kaizou Choujin Schbibinman 2: Aratanaru Teki (known as Shockman in English).

game.name: Kessen! Dokapon Oukoku IV - Densetsu no Yuusha-tachi (Japan)
game.description: Kessen! Dokapon Oukoku IV - Densetsu no Yuusha-tachi (Japan)
game.title_clean: Kessen! Dokapon Oukoku IV - Densetsu no Yuusha-tachi
game.plot: Kessen! Dokapon Okukoku IV: Densetsu no Yuusha Tachi ("Decisive Battle! Dokapon Kingdoms IV: Legend of Heroes") is a mix of an RPG and a multiplayer board game. Players move their heroes around the board, gaining levels and finding equipment, and eventually saving a kingdom from encroaching monsters. The goal is to beat the target monsters before the other players.

game.name: Kid Klown no Crazy Chase (Japan)
game.plot: Kid Klown in Crazy Chase is a platform video game developed and published by Kemco for the Super Nintendo Entertainment System. It was released in North America in September 1994, Japan on October 21, 1994 and in Europe in 1994. The game features the Kid Klown, the player character who is tasked with rescuing the Princess Honey from the villain Black Jack. Players view gameplay from an isometric perspective as Kid Klown pursues a lit fuse in order to stop it from reaching a spade bomb. The game was re-released for the Game Boy Advance and features 11 new levels, four mini-games, and a multi-player mode.

game.name: Lemmings (Japan) (En)
game.plot: Thousands of Lemmings are on the loose, marching towards extinction unless you can save them. Without minds of their own, they are completely helpless, faithfully following their leader through 125 levels of blazing fires, endless canyons, deadly tunnels and ancient ruins. You or you and a friend can command the Lemmings to dig, climb, tunnel, float and build their way to safety. But you have to move fast, because each moment you hesitate, more Lemmings may drop from above!

game.name: Lord Monarch (Japan)
game.plot: Lord Monarch is a view-limited Downloadable game for the Satellaview that was broadcast in at least 2 runs between December 20, 1997 and March 31, 1998.

game.name: Machi Magazine Idol Diary Media - Strawberry Vol. 12 (Japan)
game.description: Machi Magazine Idol Diary Media - Strawberry Vol. 12 (Japan)
game.title_clean: Machi Magazine Idol Diary Media - Strawberry Vol. 12

game.name: Mario Paint - BS Ban (Japan)
game.plot: Mario Paint BS Ban is a Downloadable Game for the Satellaview that ran between August 3, 1997 and August 30, 1997, 1998. The game is a painting tool and it functions as a pseudo-sequel to the 1992 game, Mario Paint. Between November 2, 1997 and November 22, 1997, the "Mario Paint BS Ban Contest" was held and broadcasts of the game were accompanied by a digital magazine related to the contest. The results of the contest were broadcast between December 28, 1997 and January 31, 1998 in the form of a second digital magazine accompanying the release of Mario Paint BS Ban - Yuushou Sakuhin Naizou Version.

game.name: Monopoly 2 BS - Red Cup (Japan)
game.plot: Monopoly (Japan) is a Miscellaneous game, developed and published by Tomy Corporation.

game.name: Monopoly 2 BS - Yellow Cup (Japan)
game.plot: Monopoly (Japan) is a Miscellaneous game, developed and published by Tomy Corporation.

game.name: New 3D Golf Simulation - Waialae no Kiseki (Japan)
game.description: New 3D Golf Simulation - Waialae no Kiseki (Japan)
game.title_clean: New 3D Golf Simulation - Waialae no Kiseki
game.plot: Master the Winds of Waialae![CR]Step up to the first tee and feel Hawaii's trade winds. This is Waialae-18 holes of championship action, played against the glittering backdrop of the Pacific.[CR]Every stroke tests your golf strategy. Should you hit big off the tee or lay up with an iron? Add backspin for bite? Chip-and-roll from the fringe? True Golf lets you perfect every stroke in your game.[CR]Each hole appears in perfect detail. Discover Waialae's deep-pitched bunkers on marble-slick greens. Unsure about strategy? Look for tips from the club pro.[CR]Every round serves up a new challenge. Compete with pros, or line up a foursome of friends. Check the wind, scope out the new pin placements. In True Golf, every round is a whole new game.

game.name: New Yatterman - Nandai Kandai Yajirobee (Japan) [b]
game.plot: New Yatterman: Nandai Kandai Yajirobee is a multiplayer-focused game for the Super Famicom that is based on the 1970s Yatterman anime franchise.[CR]Yatterman features a team of three heroes, all called Yatterman, who attempt to beat the supervillain team Doronbo (also a group of three) to a set of skull coins which will reveal the way to a giant treasure horde. The heroes often use toys and mechs to defeat their incompetent opponents, such as the male protagonist's kendamagic.[CR]The game is similar to First Star's Spy vs. Spy series, in that both teams are attempting to reach the treasure first. They can trip up their opponents via a number of traps, some of which have conditional uses. By burying mines and setting off missiles, the player can whittle down the health of their opponents as well as keep them off their tracks. If the two teams meet, they fight each other in a three-on-three tag team battle with the losing side taking a large hit to their health. The game can be played single-player (as either the Yatterman team or the Doronbo team) or multiplayer.

game.plot: SatellaWalker 2 is a Downloadable 2-part Soundlink game for the Satellaview that was broadcast between February 15, 1998 and February 28, 1998. SatellaWalker 2 was broadcast as the sequel to the earlier-broadcast SatellaWalker of July 1997.

game.name: Satella Walker 2 - Sate Bou o Sukuidase! (Japan) (SoundLink)
game.description: Satella Walker 2 - Sate Bou o Sukuidase! (Japan) (SoundLink)
game.title_clean: Satella Walker 2 - Sate Bou o Sukuidase!
game.plot: SatellaWalker (also known by its shorthand, SW) is a Downloadable 2-part Soundlink game for the Satellaview that was broadcast between June 29, 1997 and January 2, 1998. The game's January broadcast was the result of having been the first winner of the third Player's Choice vote. SatellaWalker was followed by a sequel, SatellaWalker 2 in February 1998.

game.name: Shanghai - Banri no Choujou (Japan) [b]
game.plot: Shanghai: Banri no Choujou is a view-limited Downloadable game for the Satellaview that was broadcast between November 15, 1998 and November 28, 1998.

game.name: Sonic Blast Man (Japan)
game.plot: His Body Is A Lethal Weapon![CR]The Sonic Blast Man is highly skilled in all forms of physical combat. With this Dynamite Punches, Flip Kicks, Judo Throws, and other fighting techniques, he uses his body to thrash enemies. As he travels around Earth and on a Space Station, he will be challenged by hundreds of human, robot, and alien foes! The Blast Man faces adventures that will push him to the limits of his skill--and beyond!

game.description: Sound Journal for Lovers - Valentine Special Vol. 1 (Japan) (SoundLink) [b]
game.title_clean: Sound Journal for Lovers - Valentine Special Vol. 1

game.name: Spriggan Powered BS - Prelude (Japan) (SoundLink)
game.plot: BS Spriggan Powered is a Downloadable 5-part Soundlink game for the Satellaview that was broadcast in at least 2 runs between May 26, 1996 and September 28, 1996.

game.name: Super Aleste (Japan)
game.plot: The game's thrilling speed is its most attractive feature. The enemy movements are fast. Your shots and the enemies' shots are fast. Finally, the scrolling is fast. The screen filled with battle action just overflows with high speed shooting excitement. On top of that there is the Shot Control System operated with the "R" button. You can attack the enemy in a multitude of ways with a weapon using this system. Naturally, the features of the Super Famicom such as rotation, enlarging, and shrinking functions are used to their fullest and huge enemies never before possible are packed into this exciting MEGA game!

game.plot: Let the games began with Super Bomberman! Invite your friends and family to join you in bombastic action!

game.title_clean: Super Puyo Puyo Tsuu BS Ban
game.plot: Puyo Puyo Tsuu BS Ban is a Downloadable game demo for the Satellaview. It is designed as a preview of the Super Famicom retail release Super Puyo Puyo Tsuu. As such, it is basically a smaller, more limited variant of that game.[CR]In the demo, the mode of play is limited to to a VS. Match between Arle and Satan, which can be played either single player (with Player 1 as Arle) or a 2-player competition.

game.plot: Super Volley II (Hyper V-Ball in the US) is a slow-paced volleyball game (figure that out!) which pits your four players against another team of four players. Can you bump, set and spike your way to victory?

game.plot: Sutte Hakkun BS Version 2 is a platform/puzzle game that was released in 1998 in Japan. As the game's title implies, it is a sequel of sorts to the earlier Sutte Hakkun (Nov. 1997) and Sutte Hakkun Event Version (Oct. 1997). A later titles in the same series, Sutte Hakkun '98 (Dec. 1998) followed a month after the broadcast of Sutte Hakkun Version 2

A later titles in the same series, Sutte Hakkun '98 (Dec. 1998) followed a month after the broadcast of Sutte Hakkun Version 2

game.name: Sutte Hakkun - BS Version 2 (Japan) (6-3)
game.plot: Sutte Hakkun BS Version 2 is a platform/puzzle game that was released in 1998 in Japan. As the game's title implies, it is a sequel of sorts to the earlier Sutte Hakkun (Nov. 1997) and Sutte Hakkun Event Version (Oct. 1997). A later titles in the same series, Sutte Hakkun '98 (Dec. 1998) followed a month after the broadcast of Sutte Hakkun Version 2

game.name: Sutte Hakkun - Event Version (Japan)
game.plot: On an island far away in the ocean, the "Rainbow of Happiness" used to stretch above the land. One day the rainbow mysteriously broke apart, separating into shards that fell on the island. Eager to return the rainbow to its magnificent self, Hakkun sets out to retrieve the shards. In the retail version the land is divided into four islands named the "Peaceful Islands" but otherwise follows the same story.[CR]The game was first released as the November portion of the Satellaview monthly game contest, and consisted of 50 levels with 5 additional bonus levels.

game.description: Table Game Daisyugo!! Shougi Mahjong Hanafuda (Japan)
game.title_clean: Table Game Daisyugo!! Shougi Mahjong Hanafuda

game.name: Tamori no Picross (8-13) + Bakushow Mondai no Houkago Ousama - Kayoubi (Japan) [b]
game.description: Tamori no Picross (8-13) + Bakushow Mondai no Houkago Ousama - Kayoubi (Japan) [b]
game.title_clean: Tamori no Picross + Bakushow Mondai no Houkago Ousama - Kayoubi

game.name: Tamori no Picross (Japan) (6-13)
game.plot: This Super Famicom version of the popular picture crossword game was originally released only in Japan and features hundreds of relaxing yet challenging brainteasers.[CR]Each Picross puzzle consists of a numbered grid of tiles which reveal a picture when correctly chiselled away. In Marios main mode, a wrong move means losing time. However, in the more difficult Wario mode, mistakes are not shown... so be careful! Also, a friend can help by joining in with a second controller.

game.name: Tamori no Picross (Japan) (6-26) [b]
game.plot: This Super Famicom version of the popular picture crossword game was originally released only in Japan and features hundreds of relaxing yet challenging brainteasers.[CR]Each Picross puzzle consists of a numbered grid of tiles which reveal a picture when correctly chiselled away. In Marios main mode, a wrong move means losing time. However, in the more difficult Wario mode, mistakes are not shown... so be careful! Also, a friend can help by joining in with a second controller.

game.name: Tamori no Picross (Japan) (8-13) [b]
game.plot: This Super Famicom version of the popular picture crossword game was originally released only in Japan and features hundreds of relaxing yet challenging brainteasers.[CR]Each Picross puzzle consists of a numbered grid of tiles which reveal a picture when correctly chiselled away. In Marios main mode, a wrong move means losing time. However, in the more difficult Wario mode, mistakes are not shown... so be careful! Also, a friend can help by joining in with a second controller.

game.name: Treasure Conflix (Japan)
game.plot: Treasure Conflix is a Downloadable game for the Satellaview that was broadcast in February 1996.

game.name: Tsuri Tarou (Japan)
game.plot: Tsuri Tarou is a Sports game, published by Pack-In-Video,which was released in Japan in 1994.

game.name: Undake 30 Same Game Daisakusen - Mario Version (Japan) [b]
game.description: Undake 30 Same Game Daisakusen - Mario Version (Japan) [b]
game.title_clean: Undake 30 Same Game Daisakusen - Mario Version
game.plot: SameGame is a Satellaview-compatible Slotted Cartridge game. The game was playable on its own without any data packs, it was playable in conjunction with 8M Pack data downloaded via the BS-X cartridge, and it could also be used together with the separately released Write-protected memory packs, Character Cassette and Character Data: Tengai Makyo.[CR]The game was eventually used to hype the release of the promotional game of the same family, UNDAKE 30 SameGame.

game.name: Wario no Mori - Futatabi (Japan)
game.plot: Wario's Woods is a falling block game where the objective is to clear the playing field of monsters by using bombs, arranging them into rows of matching colors. Unlike other puzzle games such as Tetris, where the player directly manipulates the game pieces, the player controls Toad, who moves around the playing field and arranges them after they have fallen.[CR]This game is a pseudo-sequel to the earlier-broadcast Wario's Woods.

game.name: Yoshi no Panepon - BS Ban (Japan) (En,Ja) (1-2)
game.plot: Yoshi no Panepon BS Ban is a Downloadable game for the Satellaview that was broadcast in at least 11 runs between November 3, 1996 and June 30, 2000. Yoshi no Panepon BS Ban is based on the puzzle/casual game of Panel de Pon and is a localization of the English-language release Tetris Attack.

game.name: Yoshi no Panepon - BS Ban (Japan) (En,Ja) (6-14)
game.plot: Yoshi no Panepon BS Ban is a Downloadable game for the Satellaview that was broadcast in at least 11 runs between November 3, 1996 and June 30, 2000. Yoshi no Panepon BS Ban is based on the puzzle/casual game of Panel de Pon and is a localization of the English-language release Tetris Attack.

game.name: Zelda no Densetsu - Kamigami no Triforce (Japan) (11-30)
game.description: Zelda no Densetsu - Kamigami no Triforce (Japan) (11-30)
game.title_clean: Zelda no Densetsu - Kamigami no Triforce
game.plot: Zelda no Densetsu: Kamigami no Triforce is a view-limited Downloadable game for the Satellaview that was broadcast in at least 10 distinct runs between March 2, 1997 and May 29, 2000. Unlike BS Zelda and Inishie no Sekiban, Kamigami no Triforce did not use SoundLink narration or an enhanced orchestral score. Apart from its physical form and the addition of Satellaview headers to the code, the game is identical to the hardware version released for the Super Famicom on November 21, 1991.

game.name: Zelda no Densetsu - Kamigami no Triforce (Japan) (5-21)

game.plot: Zelda no Densetsu: Kamigami no Triforce is a view-limited Downloadable game for the Satellaview that was broadcast in at least 10 distinct runs between March 2, 1997 and May 29, 2000. Unlike BS Zelda and Inishie no Sekiban, Kamigami no Triforce did not use SoundLink narration or an enhanced orchestral score. Apart from its physical form and the addition of Satellaview headers to the code, the game is identical to the hardware version released for the Super Famicom on November 21, 1991.
